etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Sheriff Court Book Orkney & Shetland. Probably from the unattested Norn reflex of the early Scandinavian word represented by Old Icelandic sími, with suffixed definite article; with the shortened stem vowel compare Swedish regional simme

definitions: A rope or band made by twisting together pieces of straw or strands of heather or other vegetation, especially one used in thatching or roofing; rope of this material.

etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Jonathan Boucher (1738–1804), schoolmaster and Church of England clergyman. Shortened from persimmon

definitions: The fruit of the American persimmon tree, Diospyros virginiana.
